channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: N Korea leader 'appears in public'
item.description: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un has made first public appearance since 3 September, the country's official news agency reports.

item.title: Shia militias 'killing Iraqi Sunnis'
item.description: Shia militias in Iraq have kidnapped and killed scores of Sunni civilians in recent months in apparent revenge for IS attacks, Amnesty International says.

item.title: Synod signals Catholic shift on gays
item.description: A report by a top-level Vatican panel on the family calls for a more positive view of homosexuals, in a move hailed by gay groups as a major shift.

item.title: MPs back Palestinian statehood
item.description: MPs vote by 274 to 12 in favour of recognising Palestine as a state alongside Israel, after a House of Commons debate.

item.title: Dozens arrested in Ferguson protests
item.description: Nearly 50 people have been arrested after crowds descended on the police station in the Missouri town where the shooting of an unarmed black teenager two months ago sparked riots.

item.title: Ebola 'could lead to failed states'
item.description: The Ebola epidemic threatens the "very survival" of societies and could lead to failed states, the World Health Organization (WHO) warns.

item.title: Iran talks resume as deadline looms
item.description: Iranian, US and EU negotiators are to hold talks in Vienna as the November deadline approaches for a final deal on Iran's nuclear programme.

item.title: Catalan leaders 'cancel referendum'
item.description: The Catalan regional government has called off plans to push ahead with a contested independence referendum, Spanish media says.

item.title: Oklahoma to delay three executions
item.description: The attorney general of the US state of Oklahoma is seeking to delay three executions, claiming more time is needed to obtain necessary drugs.

item.title: Anger over Pistorius sentence call
item.description: A call for Oscar Pistorius to carry out community service for killing girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp, sparks an angry prosecution response.

item.title: 'Fear' in US hostage's letter home
item.description: Abdul-Rahman Kassig, held by IS militants and threatened with murder, says "the stress and fear are incredible" in a letter to his parents in Indiana.

item.title: Royal hoax DJ tells of death threats
item.description: A radio DJ, who took part in a hoax call after which a nurse killed herself, tells Newsnight how she received death threats and bullets in the post.

item.title: VIDEO: Vaccine race for 'enemy' Ebola virus
item.description: The BBC's David Shukman reports on the race to develop a vaccine and treatment for Ebola, which health officials are describing as ''the enemy''.

item.title: VIDEO: Typhoon Vongfong hits Japan islands
item.description: Typhoon Vongfong, the strongest storm to hit Japan this year. makes landfall on the country's main islands.

item.title: VIDEO: Viking treasure trove found in field
item.description: A Viking treasure trove thought to be worth a six-figure sum is unearthed in a field in Dumfriesshire by a man using a metal detector.

item.title: VIDEO: One-minute World News
item.description: Watch the latest news summary from BBC World News. International news updated 24 hours a day.

item.title: VIDEO: Record-breaking firework in Japan
item.description: A new world record has been set for the heaviest firework in the city of Konosu in Saitama Prefecture, Japan

item.title: VIDEO: New Indian football league kicks off
item.description: A new Indian football league is launching on Sunday, in a country where cricket has traditionally been a more popular sport.

item.title: VIDEO: UK government to sell Eurostar stake
item.description: The UK government is seeking buyers for its 40% stake in the cross-Channel train operator Eurostar to help boost the public finances but Labour warns against a "rushed" sell-off.

item.title: VIDEO: Cuba circus kids 'go professional'
item.description: In Cuba, young children are learning circus skills with a view to becoming professional performers.

item.title: Australian chain pulls 'racist' top
item.description: Australian store pulls 'racist' top

item.title: Sanctions hit space food supply
item.description: Ukraine sanctions 'hit space food supply'

item.title: Asian shares mixed after US fall
item.description: Asian shares are lower following a sell-off on Wall Street as investors worry about how weak global growth would impact company earnings.

item.title: Oil prices see further declines
item.description: Global oil prices fall again amid worries about sluggish global growth and reports that key oil producers want to maintain current output levels.

item.title: Nude 'Snapchat images' put online
item.description: Explicit images believed to have been sent through Snapchat are reportedly put online, but the firm says its servers were not breached.

item.title: Samsung accelerates wi-fi speeds
item.description: Electronics giant Samsung claims to have overcome technical hurdles that will let its gadgets beam data around at speeds of 4.6Gbps.

item.title: Witherspoon role 'hardest' of career
item.description: Actress Reese Witherspoon says her new film Wild - about a young woman's 1,000-mile hike across America - was the most challenging of her career to date.

item.title: Finnigan apologises for rape comments
item.description: TV star Judy Finnigan apologises after comments she made about convicted rapist Ched Evans on ITV's Loose Women show prompted a Twitter backlash.

item.title: UK waters face 'invasional meltdown'
item.description: Scientists warn that an army of organisms from Turkey and Ukraine is poised to invade Britain's waterways and destroy native species.

item.title: Snail named after marriage equality
item.description: A new species of hermaphrodite land snail found in Taiwan has been named in support of marriage equality.

item.title: Liberia Ebola medics ignore strike
item.description: Nurses and medical assistants fighting the Ebola outbreak in Liberia largely ignore a call to strike over danger money and conditions.

item.title: Frozen faeces in gut infection trial
item.description: Capsules containing frozen faecal material could help people with C. difficile gut infections, results from an early-stage trial suggest.

item.title: Hodgson questions Rodgers's claims
item.description: England boss Roy Hodgson questions Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers's claim that some players need a two-day recovery period.

item.title: Man Utd needed signings - Ferguson
item.description: Former Manchester United boss Sir Alex Ferguson admits the squad needed "a big injection" of players after finishing seventh.

item.title: The First Spacewalk
item.description: How the first human to take steps in outer space nearly didn't return to Earth

item.title: Hip hop, race and protests in Ferguson
item.description: The BBC is visiting five states in five days to test the mood in America ahead of the mid-term elections. First stop: A hip hop show in Ferguson, Missouri.

item.title: Somalia launches postal service
item.description: Somalia launches its first postal service in more than two decades, in another sign of normality returning to the conflict-torn country.

item.title: Taliban 'kill 22' in mountain ambush
item.description: Taliban insurgents in Afghanistan kill at least 22 security force members in an ambush in Sar-e-Pol province north of Kabul, officials say.

item.title: East Ukraine rebel leader attacked
item.description: A pro-Russian Donetsk rebel leader, Pavel Gubarev, is unconscious in hospital after gunmen fired at his car, causing it to crash.

item.title: Leaders hail Evo Morales 'victory'
item.description: Latin American leaders congratulate Evo Morales after he claims victory in Bolivia's presidential election, securing a third term in office.

item.title: Thousands flee IS in Anbar, says UN
item.description: As many as 180,000 people have fled after Islamic State militants overran the Iraqi city of Hit in western Anbar province, the UN says.

item.title: US braces for more Ebola infections
item.description: US public health workers "would not be surprised" to see additional Ebola infections among hospital staff, a senior US official says.

item.title: Heathrow to start screening for Ebola
item.description: Heathrow airport is to start Ebola screening for passengers flying into the UK from at-risk countries.

item.title: Cantlie's sister in new appeal to IS
item.description: The sister of British hostage John Cantlie, who is being held by Islamic State, makes an appeal for "direct contact" with the militants.

item.title: GPs missing signs for lung cancer
item.description: Doctors in Britain are "missing opportunities" to spot lung cancer at an early stage, meaning one in three people with the disease dies within 90 days of diagnosis, research suggests.

item.title: NHS staff strike in dispute over pay
item.description: Thousands of health workers in England and Northern Ireland have taken part in a strike over pay for the first time for more than 30 years.

item.title: In pictures: Urban photography competition winners
item.description: Winners of Urban Photo of the Year competition

item.title: Day in pictures: 13 October
item.description: 24 hours of news images: 13 October

item.title: In pictures: Life in Chechnya
item.description: Award winning photos by Davide Monteleone

item.title: Week in pictures: 4-10 October 2014
item.description: Best news photos from around the world

item.title: In pictures: Army Photographic Awards
item.description: Winning shots from the Army Photographic Awards

item.title: Day in pictures: 10 October
item.description: 24 hours of news images: 10 October

item.title: Your pictures: Dance
item.description: Readers' photos on the theme of "dance"

item.title: Speakers' Corner in pictures
item.description: Debate and disagreement at London's Speakers' Corner

item.title: Copenhagen's piles of bicycles
item.description: A city where so many cycle it's hard to find a place to park

item.title: VIDEO: Vegas hosts $1m chess tournament
item.description: Las Vegas hosts million-dollar chess tournament

item.title: The 1940s bandleader who braved virulent sexism
item.description: Melanie C on the 1940s bandleader who braved virulent sexism

item.title: Show paints Rembrandt as 'modern' artist
item.description: New exhibition paints Rembrandt as 'modern' artist

item.title: The police officers fired for a kiss
item.description: The photograph that got three police officers fired

item.title: China's controversial philanthropist
item.description: The singing billionaire whose charity work courts controversy

item.title: How IS conflict has changed Iran nuclear talks
item.description: How the rise of IS has affected Iran's nuclear talks

item.title: Bulgaria's military faces modernisation 'catastrophe'
item.description: Bulgaria warned to abandon Soviet-era military hardware

item.title: Empty nest syndrome when a child has a learning disability
item.description: What is like when a disabled child leaves home?

item.title: How in a single year did life expectancy in the US drop by 12 years?
item.description: Why did life expectancy in the US drop by 12 years after WW1?

item.title: Pistorius sentence: Defence battles to avoid jail
item.description: The athlete's defence team battles to avoid jail

item.title: New website tracks MEPs' extra cash
item.description: Watchdog reveals how much extra cash some MEPs are making
